Botts Tear-chops Spill-blood 1 Sergeant 2 Sergeant Drawer Page Both/Omnes Servant Count Priest UNK

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div2.stage: Enter the Lady Honor, the Lady Perfect, the Lady Bright.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: A Wife the happiest state? It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Yes, such a wife as I, that have a man
As if myself had made him: such a one
As I may justly say, I am the rib
Belonging to his breast. Widow and Maid,
Your lives compared to mine are miserable,
Though wealth and beauty meet in each of you.
Poor virgin, all thy sport is thought of love,
And meditation of a man, the time
And circumstance ere thou canst fix thy thoughts
On one thy fancy will approve.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: That trouble already may be past.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Why if it be.
The doubt, he will not hold his brittle saith,
That he is not a compatible choice,
And so your noble friends will cross the match,
Doth make your happiness uncertain still:
Or say you married him, what he would prove.
Can you compare your state then to a Wife?

sp.speaker: Maide.
sp.p:
Nay, all the freedom that a virgin hath
Is much to be preferred. who would endure
The humours of so insolent a Thing
As is a husband? Which of all the Heard
Runs not possessed with some notorious vice,
Drinking or whoring, fighting, Jealousy,
Even of a Page at twelve, or of a Groom,
That rubs horse-heels? Is it not daily seen,
Men take wives, but to dress their meat, to wash
And starch their linen: for the other matter
Of lying with them, that is but when they please:
And whatsoever the joy be of the bed,
The pangs that follow procreation
Are hideous, or you wives have gulled your husbands
With your loud shriekings, and your deathful throes.
A Wife or Widow to a Virgins life?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p:
Why should the best of you think ye enjoy
The rest and rule, that a free widow doth?
I am mine own commander, and the bliss
Of wooers, and of each variety
Frequents me, as I were a maid. No Brother
Have I to dice my patrimony away, as you
My maiden Madam may. No husbands death
Stand I in doubt on: for thanks be to heaven
(If mine were good) the grievous loss of him
Is not to come; if he were bad, he is gone,
And I no more embrace my injury.
But be yours ill, you nightly clasp your hate;
Or good, why he may dye, or change his virtue.
And thou (though single) hast a bed-fellow
As bad as the worst husband, thought of one,
And what that is, men with their wives do do,
And long expectance till the deed be done.
"A wife is like a garment used and torn:
"A maid like one made up, but never worn.

sp.speaker: Maide.
sp.p:
"A widow is a garment worn thread-bare,
Selling at second hand, like Brokers ware.
But let us speak of things the present time
Make happy to us, and see what is best.
I have a servant then the crown of men,
The fountain of Humanity, the prize
Of every virtue, Moral and Divine;
Young, valiant, learned, well-borne, rich and shaped
As if wife Nature when she fashioned him,
Had meant to give him nothing but his form,
Yet all additions are conferred on him,
That may delight a woman: this same youth
To me hath sacrificed his heart, yet I
Have checked his suite, laughed at his worthy service,
Made him the exercise of my cruelty,
Whilst constant as the Sun, for all these clouds
His love goes on.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Peace, here is the man you name.

sp.speaker: Wife., Widow.
sp.p: We will stand aside.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Good morrow to the glory of our age.
The Lady Perfect, and the Lady Bright,
The virtuous wife and widow: but to you
The Lady Honour, and my Mistress.
The happiness of your wishes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
By this light, I never heard one speak so scurvily,
Utter such stale wit, and pronounce so ill.
But to you,
My Lady Honour, and my Mistress,
The happiness of your wishes.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p:
Stop your wit,
You would fain show these Ladies what a hand
You hold over your servant. It shall not need,
I will express your tyranny well enough.
I have loved this Lady since I was a child,
Since I could construe Amo: now she says
I do not love her, because I do not weep,
Lay mine arms over my heart, and wear no gaiters,
Walk with mine eyes in my hat, sigh, and make faces
For all the Poets in the town to laugh at,
Pox on this howling love, it is like a dog
Shut out at midnight. Must love needs be powdered,
Lie steeped in brine; or will it not keep sweet?
Is it like beef in summer?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Did you ever
Hear one talk fustian like a Butcher thus?

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p:
It is foolish, this same telling folks we love,
It needs no words, it will show itself in deeds,
And did I take you for an entertainer,
A Lady that will wring one by the finger,
Whilst on another's toes she treads, and cries
By Gad I love but one, and you are he:
Either of them thinking himself the man,
I would tell you in your ear, put for the business,
Which granted, or denied, Madam God be with ye.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Come these are daily slanders that you raise,
On our infirm and unresisting Sex,
You never met I am sure with such a Lady.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p:
O many by this light, I have seen a Chamber
Frequented like an office of the Law,
Clients succeed at midnight one another:
Whilst the poor Madam hath been so distressed,
Which of her Loves to show most countenance to,
That herdull Husband has perceived her wiles.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Nay perhaps taught her, many of those Husbands
Are base enough
To live upon it.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p:
I have seen another of them
Cheat by this light at Cards, and set her women,
To talk to the Gentlemen that played,
That so distracted they might over see.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: O fie upon ye, I dare swear you lie.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p: Do not fair Mistress, you will be forsworn.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
You men are all foul mouthed, I warrant, you
Talk thus of me and other Ladies here,
Because we keep the City.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p:
O profane.
That thought would damn me, will you marry yet?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: No I will never marry.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p:
Shall we then
Couple unlawfully? for indeed this marrying
Is but proclaiming what we mean to do;
Which may be done privately, in civil sort
And none the wiser, and by this white hand La:
The wrack, Strappado, or the boiling boot,
Should never force me tell to wrong your honour.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: May I believe this?

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p: Let it be your Creed.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
But if you should prove false. Nay never unhang
Your sword, except you mean to hang yourself:
Why where have you been drinking? 'sfoot you talk
Like one of these same rambling boys,
That reign in Turnebull-street.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Indeed my knowledge, is but speculative
Not practic there, I have it by Relation,
From such observers as yourself dear Servant,
I must profess, I did think well of thee,
But get thee from my sight, I never more
Will hear or see thee, but will hate thee deadly,
As a man enemy, or a woman turned.
Ladies come forth, see Sir what Courtesy
You have done to me, a strange praise of you
Had newly left my lips, just, as you entered,
And how you have deserved it, with your carriage?
Villain, thou hast hurt mine honour to these friends,
For what can they imagine but some ill
Hath past betwixt us by thy broad discourse?
Were my case theirs, by Virgin Chastity,
I should condemn them: hence, depart my sight.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p:
Madam, but hear me, O that these were men,
And durst but say or think you ill, for this
I have so good a cause upon my side,
That I would cut their hearts out of their breasts:
And the thoughts out of them that injured you.
But I obey your best, and for my penance,
Will run a course never to see you more,
And now I lose you, may I lose the light:
Since in that beauty dwelt my day or night.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Is this the virtuous youth?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Your happiness?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Wherein you thought your seat so far above ours,

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
If one man could be good, this had been he.
See here comes all your suitors, and your Husband,
And room for Laughter, here is the Lord Feesimple,
What Gentlewoman does he bring along?

div2.stage: Enter Hvsband, embracing Svbtle, the Lord Feesimple, with young Bovld like awaiting Gentlewoman.VVel-tri'd, Hvsb: Svbtle talke withWife .

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p:
One and thirty good-morrows to the fairest, wisest,
chastest, richest Widow that ever conversation coped
withal.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p:
Three score and two unto the wisest Lord,
That ever was trained in university.

sp.speaker: Feesimp.
sp.p:
O Courteous, bounteous Widow, she has outbid
me thirty-one. Good morrows at a clap.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
But my Lord Feesimple you forgot the business imposed
on you.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p:
Gentlewoman, I cry thee mercy, but it is a fault in
all Lords, not in me only,we do use to swear by our Honours:
and as we are Noble, to dispatch such a business for
such a Gentleman and we are bound, even by the same
Honours we swear by, to forget it in a quarter of an hour.
And look as if we had never seen the Party, when we
meet next, especially if none of our Gentlemen have been
considered.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Aye, but all yours have, for you keep none my Lord:
Besides though it stands with your Honour to forget men's
businesses; yet it stands not with your Honour, if you do not
do a woman's.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Why then Madam, so it is that I request your Ladyship
to accept into your service this Gentlewoman, for
her truth and honesty I will be bound, I have known her too
long to be deceived, this is the second time I have seen her.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Why how now my Lord: a profferer of Gentlewomen
to service like an old knitting woman? where hath
She dwelt before.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
She dwelt with young Boulds sister, he that is my
Corival in your Love, she requested me to advance her to
You; for you are a dubbed Lady: so is not she yet.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
But now you talk of young Bould, when did you see
him Lady?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Not this month Master Well-tri'd.
I did conjure him to forbear my sight:
Indeed swore if he came I would be denied,
But it is strange you should ask for him, ye two were wont
never to be asunder.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Faith Madam we never were together but we
differd on some argument or other,
And doubting lest our discord might at length
Breed to some quarrel, I forbear him too.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p:
He quarrel? Bould: hang him, if he durst have quarrelled,
the world knows he is within a mile of an oak has
put him to it, and soundly, I never cared for him in my life,
but to see his sister, he is an ass, pox an arrant ass, for do
you think any but an arrant ass, would offer to come a-wooing,
where a Lord attempts? he quarrel: he dares not quarrel.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
But he dares fight my Lord, upon my knowledge,
And rail no more my Lord, behind his back,
For if you do my Lord blood must ensue.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: O, O, my honour dies, I am dead.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Uds light what is the matter, wring him by the nose

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: A pair of riding spurs now were worth gold,

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Pins are as good, prick him, prick him

sp.speaker: Feesim.
sp.p: O, O.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: He has come again, lift him up.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: How fares your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p:
O friends, you have wronged my spirit to call it
back, I was even in Elisium at rest.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: But why sir did you swoon?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Well though I die Master Wel-tri'd before all these
I do forgive you, because you were ignorant of my infirmity,
O sir, is it not up yet, I die again, put up now whilst
I wink, or I do wink for ever.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
It is up my Lord, ope your eyes, but I pray tell me
Is this antipathy betwixt bright steel and you natural, or
how grew it?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
I will tell you sir, anything bright and edged, works
thus strongly with me, your hilts now I can handle as boldly,
look you else.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p:
Nay never blame my Lord, Master Well-tri'd, for
I know a great many will sown at the sight of a shoulder
of mutton or a quarter of Lamb, my Lord may be excused
then, for a naked sword.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
This Lord, and this knight in dog-collars would
make a fine brace of beagles.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
But on my faith it was mightily overseen of your
father, not to bring you up to foils, or if he had bound
you Prentice to a Cutler or an Ire-monger.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p:
Aye a pox, hang him old gouty fool, he never brought
me up to any Lordly exercise, as fencing, dancing, tumbling,
and such like: but forsooth I must write and read, and speak
languages, and such base qualities, fit for none but Gentlemen.
Now sir would I tell him, Father you are a Count, I
am a Lord a pox on writing and reading, and languages, let
me be brought up as I was born.

sp.speaker: Subtle.
sp.p:
But how my Lord came you first not to endure the
sight of steel.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Why I will tell you Sir, when I was a child, an infant,
an Innocent.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: It was even now.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p:
I being in the kitchen, in my Lord my fathers house,
the Cook was making minced pies: so sir, I standing by the
Dresser, there lay a heap of plums. Here was he mincing;
what did me I sir, being a not able little witty coxcomb,
but popped my hand just under his chopping knife, to snatch
some Raisins, and so was cut over the hand, and never since
could I endure the sight of any edge-tool.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Indeed they are not fit for you my Lord, and now
you are all so well satisfied in this matter, pray Ladies now
like you this my Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
In troth Madam exceeding well Aye, if you be provided,
pray let me have her.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: It should be my request, but that I am full.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What can you do? What is her name my Lord?

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: Her name? I know not. What is her name Mister Well-try'd?

sp.speaker: Weltr.
sp.p: Her name? slid, tell my Lady your name.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Mistress Mary Princox forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Mistress Mary Princox: she has wit, I perceive that
already. Methinks she speaks as if she were a my Lords
brood.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Brood Madam, it is well known I am a Gentlewoman.
My father was a man of five hundred per annum, and he
held something in Capite too.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: So does my Lord, something.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p:
Nay, by my troth, what I hold in capite is worth little
or nothing.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
I have had apt breeding, however my misfortune
now makes me submit myself to service: but there is
no ebb so low, but hath his tide again: when our days
are at worst, they will mend in spite of the frowning Destinies,
For we cannot be lower than earth, and the same
blind Dame that hath cast her blear eyes hitherto upon
my occasions, may turn her wheel, and at last wind them
up with her white hand to some pinnacle that prosperously
may flourish in the Sunshine of promotion.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p:
O mouth, full of agility, I would give twenty Marks
now to any person that could teach me to convey my
tongue (sans stumbling) with such dexteritie to such a period.
For her truth and her honesty I am bound before, but
now I have heard her talk, for her wit I will be bound body
and goods.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Uds light, I will not leave her for my hood.
I never met with one of these eloquent old Gentlewomen
before. What age are you Mistress Mary Princox?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
I will not lie Madam, I have numbered fifty-seven Summers,
and just so many winters have I past.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
But they have not past you, they lie frozen in your
face.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Madam, if it shall please you to entertain me, so:
if not, I desire you not to misconstrue my good will, there is
no harm done, the door is as big as it was, and your Ladyship's
own wishes crown your beauty with content. As for
these frumping Gallants, let them do their worst: it is not
in man's power to hurt me: it is well known I come not
to be scoffed. A woman may bear and bear till her back
burst. I am a poor Gentlewoman, and since virtue has nowadays no other companion but poverty, I set the Hares
head against the Goole giblets, and what I want one way
I hope I shall be enabled to supply the other.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: If it please God, that thou wert not past children;

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Is it even so my Lord? nay good Princox do not cry,
I do entertain you, how do you occupy? what can you
use?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Anything fit to be put into the hands of a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What are your qualities?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
I can sleep on a low stool, if your Lady-ship be
talking in the same room with any Gentle-man, I can read
on a book, sing love songs, look up at the louvre light,
hear and be deaf, see and be blind, be ever dumb to your
secrets, swear and equivocate, and whatsoever I spy, say
the best.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
O rare Crone? how art thou endued? but why did
Master Boulds sister put you away?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
I beseech you Madam to neglect that desire,
though I know your Lady-ships understanding to be sufficient
to partake or take in the greatest secret; can be imparted:
yet. -

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Nay prithee tell the cause, come here is none but
friends.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Faith Madam, heigh ho, I was (to confess truly)
a little foolish in my last service, to believe men's oaths, but
I hope my example, though prejudicial to myself, will be
beneficial to other young Gentle-women in service, my mistresses
brother (the Gentle-man you named even now, master
Bould) having often attempted my honour, but finding it impregnable,
vowed love, and marriage to me, at the last, I, a
young thing and raw, being seduced, set my mind upon him,
but friends contradicting the match, I fell into a grievous
consumption, and upon my first recovery, lest the intended
sacred ceremonies of Nuptials should succeed, his sister
knowing this, thought it fit in her judgment, we should be
farther a sunder, and so put me out of her service.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
God a mercy for this discovery i'faith,
O man what art thou? when thy cock is up? come will your
lordship walk in? it is dinner time.

div2.stage: Enter hastily M. Seldome with papers on his arme.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Who is this? who is this?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
This is our Land-lord, Master Seldom,
An exceeding wise Citizen, a very sufficient understanding
man, and exceeding rich.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Miracles are not seized.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Good morrow Land-lord, where have you been
sweating?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p:
Good morrow to your Honours, thrift is industrious,
your Lady-ship knows we will not stick to sweat for our
pleasures, how much more ought we to sweat for our profits?
I am come from master Ingen this morning who is married
or to be married, and though your Ladyships did not
honour his Nuptials with your presence, he hath by me sent
each of you a pair of gloves, and Grace Seldom my wife is
not forgot.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: God give him joy, God give him joy.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Let all things most impossible change now.
O perjured man! oaths are but words I see.
But wherefore should not we that think we love
Upon full merit, that same worth once ceasing
Surcease our love to, and find new desert?
Alas we cannot, love is a pit, which, when
We fall into we never get out again,
And this same horrid news which me assaults
I would forget, love blanches blackest faults:
O! what path shall I tread for remedy?
But darkest shades, where love with death doth lie.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Sir I have often heard my husband speak of your
acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
Nay my virtuous wife,
Had it been but acquaintance, this his absence
Had not appeared so uncouth, but we two
Were School-fellows together, born and nursed,
Brought up, and lived since like the Gemins,
Had but one suck, the Tavern or the Ordinary.
Ere I was married, that saw one of us
Without the other, said we walked by halves,
Where dear, dear friend have you been all this while?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
O most sweet friend the World is so vicious,
That had I with such familiarity
Frequented you since you were married,
Possessed and used your fortunes as before,
As in like manner you commanded mine,
The depraved thoughts of men would have proclaimed
Some scandalous rumours from this love of ours,
As saying, mine reflected on your Lady,
And what a wound had that been to our souls?
When only friend-ship should have been the ground
To hurt her Honour, and your confident peace,
Spite of mine own approved integrity.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
Wife, kiss him, bid him welcome pox on the World,
Come, come you shall not part from me in haste,
I do command thee use this Gentle-man
In all things like myself, if I should die
I would bequeath him in my will to thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Sir, you are most welcome, and let scandalous tongues
No more deterre you, I dare use you Sir,
With all the right belonging to a friend,
And what I dare, I dare let all men see
My conscience rather, than men's thoughts be free.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
Will you look in?
We will follow you. Now friend
What think you of this Lady?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Why sweet friend,
That you are happy in her, she is fair,
Witty and virtuous, and was rich to you,
Can there be an addition to a wife?

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
Yes, constancy, for it is not chastity
That lives remote from all attempters free,
But there, it is strong and pure where all that woo
It doth resist, and turns them virtuous too;
Therefore dear friend, by this, love's masculine kiss,
By all our mutual engagements past,
By all the hopes of amity to come,
Be you the settler of my jealous thoughts,
And make me kill my fond suspect of her,
By assurance that she is loyal, otherwise
That she is false, and then, as she is past cure,
My soul shall ever after be past care.
That you are fittest for this enterprise
You must needs understand, since prove she true
(In this your trial) you my dearest friend,
(Whom only, rather than the World besides
I would have satisfied of her virtue) shall be,
And best conceal my folly, prove she weak,
It is better you should know it than any man,
who can reform her, and do me no wrong,
Chemical metals, and bright gold itself
By sight are not distinguished, but by the test,
Thought makes good wives, but trial makes the best:
To the unskilful owners eyes, alike
The Bristow sparkles as the Diamond,
But by a Lapidary the truth is found,
Come you shall not deny me.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Do not wrong
So fair a wife (friend) and so virtuous,
Whose good name is a theme unto the World,
Make not a wound with searching where was none,
Misfortune still such projects doth pursue,
He makes a false wife, that suspects a true;
Yet since you so importune, give me leave
To ruminate a while, and I will straight
Follow and give you an answer.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: You must do it.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Assure yourself dear - Coxcomb, I will do it
Or strangely be denied, all is as I wished,
This was my aim, although I have seemed strange.
I know this fellow now to be an Ass;
A most unworthy husband though in view
He bear himself thus fair, she knows this too,
Therefore the stronger are my hopes to gain her:
And my dear friend that will have your wife tried,
I will try her first, then thrust her if I can,
And as you said most wisely I hoped to be
Both Touch-stone to your wife and Lapidary.

div2.stage: Enter Seldome his Wife working as in their shop.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
Husband these gloves are not fit for my wearing,
I will put them into the shop and sell them, you shall
give me a plain pair for them.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p:
This is wonderful, wonderful, this is thy sweet care
and judgment in all things, this goodness is not usual in
our wives, well Grace Seldom, that thou art fair is nothing,
that thou art well spoken is nothing, that thou art witty is
nothing, that thou art a Citizens wife is nothing; but Grace,
that thou art fair, that thou art well spoken, that thou art
witty, that thou art a Citizens wife, and that thou art honest
I say, and let any mun deny it that can, it is something,
it is something, I say, it is Seldomes something, and for all
the Sunshine of my joy mine eyes must rain upon thee.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p:
By your leave Master Seldom, have you done the
hangers I bespake for the Knight?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p: Yes marry have I Mistress hic et hæac, I will fetch them to you.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p:
Z'oones, does not your husband know my name, if
it had been somebody else I would have called him Cuckoldly slave.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: If it had been somebody else perhaps you might.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p:
Well I may be even with him, all is clear; pretty
rogue I have longed to know thee this twelve months, and
had no other means but this to speak with thee, there is a
letter to thee from the party.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: What party?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: The Knight Sir Iohn Louall.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
Hence lewd impudent
I know not what to term thee man or woman,
For nature shaming to acknowledge thee
For either; hath produced thee to the World
Without a sex, some say thou art a woman,
Others a man; and many thou art both
Woman and man, but I think rather neither
Or man and horse, as the old Centaurs were feigned.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p:
Why how now Mistress, what lack ye? are you so
so fine with a pox? I have seen a woman look as modestly
as you, and speak as sincerely, and follow the Friars as
zealously, and she has been as sound a jumbler as ever paid
for it, it is true Mistress. Fipenie, I have sworn to leave this letter.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
Do ye hear, you sword and target (to speak in
your own key) Marie Umbree, Long-Meg,
Thou that in thyself (me thinkst) alone
Lookest like a rogue and a whore under a hedge:
Bawd, take your letter with you and begone,
When next you come (my Husband's Constable)
And Bridewell is hard by, You have a good wit,
And can conceive.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p: Look you, here are the hangers.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p:
Let us see them.
Fie, fie, you have mistook me quite,
They are not for my turn (bye mistress Seldome)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Here is my Lord Proudly.

sp.speaker: Lo. Proud.
sp.p: My Horse Lackey, is my sister Honour above?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p:
I think her Ladyship, my Lord, is not well, and keeps
her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: All is one, I must see her, have the other Ladies. din'd?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I think not my Lord.

div2.stage: Enter Page with a pipe of Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
Then I will take a pipe of Tobacco here in your
shop if it be not offensive, I would be loath to be thought to
come just at dinner time. Garcon; fill, sirrah,
What said the Gold-Smith for the money?

div2.stage: Seldome hauing fetch a candle, walk's off at th'other end of the Shop, Lord sits by his wife.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
He said my Lord he would lend no man money
that he durst not arrest.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
How got that wit into Cheape-side 'tro, he is a
Cuckold.
Saw you my Lady today, what says she?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Marry my Lord, she said her old husband had a
great payment to make this morning, and had not left her
so much as a jewel.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
A pox of her old Cats chops, the teeth she had,
have made a transmigration into hair, she hath a bigger
beard than I by this light.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p:
This custom in us Citizens is good,
Thus walking off when men talk with our wives,
It shows us courteous, and mannerly,
Some count it baseness, he is a fool that does so,
It is the highest point of policy
Especially when we have virtuous wives.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Fie, fie, you talk uncivilly my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Uncivilly, mew, can a Lord talk uncivilly? I think
you a finical taffeta pipkin may be proud I will sit so near it,
uncivilly mew.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Your mothers Cat has kittened in your mouth sure:

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Prithee but note yon Fellow, does he not walk and look
as if he did desire to be a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p:
But you do not look as if you could make him one,
now they have dind my Lord.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: God save your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: How dost thou Cuz, hast thou got any more wit yet?

sp.speaker: Feesim.
sp.p:
No by my troth I have but little money with that
little wit I have, and the more wit ever the less money, yet
as little as I have of either: I would give something that I durst but quarrel,
I would not be abused thus daily as I am.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Save you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p:
Good Master Wel-tri'd, you can inform me, pray
how ended the quarrel betwixt young Bould, and the other
Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Why very fairly my Lord, on honourable terms,
Young Bould was injured and did challenge him,
Fought in the field, and the other gave him satisfaction
Under his hand, I was Boulds second, and can show it here.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
It is strange there was no hurt done, yet I hold
the other Gentleman, far the better Man.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: So do not I.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Besides they say the satisfaction that walks in the Ordinaries,
is counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
He lies that says so, and I will make it good,
And for I know my friend is out of town,
What Man soever wrongs him is my foe,
I say he had full satisfaction,
Nay that which we may call submission:
That the other sought peace first, and who denies this,
Lord, Knight, or Gentleman, English, French, or Scot,
I will fight and prove it on him with my sword.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
No sweet Master Well-tri'd, let us have no fighting
till (as you have promised) you have rid me from this foolish
fear, and taught me to endure to look upon a naked Sword.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Well and I will be as good as my word.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
But do you hear Cozen Proudly? they say my old
Father must marry your sister Honour, and that he will disinherit
me, and entail all his Lordships on her, and the heir
he shall beget on her body, is it true or not?

sp.speaker: Proudly.
sp.p: There is such a report.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Why then I pray God he may die an old Cuckoldly
slave, O world what art thou? where is Parents love?
Can he deny me for his natural Child,
Yet see (O fornicator) old and stiff,
Not where he should be, that is my comfort yet,
As for you my Lord: I will send to you as soon as I dare
fight and look upon steel, which Master Wel-tri'd I pray
let be with all possible speed.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: What do ye this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Faith I have a great mind to see long-megg and he
ship at the Fortune.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Nay i'faith let us up and have a rest at Primero.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Agreed my Lord, and toward the Evening I will carry
you to the Company.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Well no more words.

div2.stage: Exeunt Lord Provdly, Lord Fees. Wel-tr.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
I wonder Sir you will walk so and let anybody
fit prating to your wife! were I a man I would thrust them out of the
shop by the head and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p:
There were no policy in that wife, so should I lose
their custom, let them talk themselves weary, and give
thee love tokens still, I lose not by it.
Thy chastity is impregnable, I know it,
Had I a dame whose eyes did swallow youth,
Whose unchaste gulf together did take in
Masters, and Men, the Foot-boys and their Lords,
Making a Gallimaufry in her blood,
I would not walk thus then: but virtuous wife,
He that in chaste ears pours his ribald talk
Begets hate to himself, and not consent;
And even as dirt thrown hard against a wall
Rebounds and sparkles in the throwers eyes,
So ill words uttered to a virtuous Dame,
Turn and defile the speaker with red shame.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p:
Z'oones, you are a whore, though I entreat him fair
Before his face, in complement, or so,
I not esteem him truly as this rush,
There is no such thing as friend-ship in the world,
And he that cannot swear, dissemble, lie,
Wants knowledge how to live, and let him die.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Sir I did think you had esteemed of him
As you made show, therefore I used him well,
And yet not so but that the strictest eye
I durst have made a witness of my carriage.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
Plague a your carriage, why he kissed your hand,
Looked babies in your eyes, and winked and pinked,
You thought I had esteemed him, S'blood you whore,
Do not I know, that you do know you lie,
When didst thou hear me say and mean one thing?
O I could kick you now, and tear your face
And eat thy Breasts like udders.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Sir you may, but if I know what hath deserved all this
I am no woman, because he kissed my hand, unwillingly.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: A little louder pray.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
You are a base fellow, an unworthy man
As ever poor Gentlewoman matched withal,
Why should you make such show of love to any
Without the truth, thy beastly mind is like
Some decayed Tradesman that doth make his wife
Entertain those for gain he not endures,
Pish, swell and burst, I had rather with thy sword
Be hewed to pieces, than lead such a life,
Out with it valiant sir, I hold you for
A drawer upon women, not on men,
I will no more conceal your hollow heart,
But even report you as you are in truth.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: This is called marriage, stop your mouth you whore.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Thy mother was a whore if I be one.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p:
You know there is company in the house, sweet friend
What have you writ your letter?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p:
It is done, dear friend, I have made you stay too long
I fear you will be benighted.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
Fie, no, no,
Madam and sweetest wife farewell, God bless us,
Make much of master Subtle here my friend
Till my return, which may be even as it happens,
According as my business hath success.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: How will you pass the time, now fairest Mistress.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
In troth I know not, wives without their husbands
Methinks are lowering days.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Indeed some wives
Are like dead bodies in their Husbands absence.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
If any Wife be, I must needs be so
That have a Husband far above all men,
Untainted with the humours others have,
A perfect man, and one that loves you truly,
You see the charge he left of your good usage.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Push, he is an Ass, I know him, a stark Ass.
Of a most barbarous condition,
False-hearted to his friend, rough unto you,
A most dissembling and perfidious fellow,
I care not if he heard me, this I know,
And will make good upon him with my sword
Or any for him, for he will not fight.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Fie servant, you show small civility
And less humanity, do ye requite
My husbands love thus ill, or what do ye think
Of me, that you will utter to my face
Such harsh, unfriendly, slanderous injuries
Even of my Husband? Sir, forbear I pray
My ears, or your own tongue, I am no housewife
To hear my Husbands merit thus depraved.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
His merit is a halter by this light,
You think he is out of Town now, no such matter
But gone aside, and hath importuned me
To try your chastity.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
It cannot be,
Alas he is as free from jealousy,
And ever was as confidence itself,
I know he loves me too, too heartily
To be suspicious, or to prove my truth.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
If I do fain in aught, never may I purchase
The grace I hope for, and fair Mistress
If you have any spirit, or wit, or sense,
You will be even with such a wretched slave,
Heaven knows I love you, as the air I draw,
Think but how finely you may cuckold him,
And safely too, with me, who will report
To him, that you are most invincible,
Your Chastity not to be subdued by man.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: When you know, I am a whore.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
A whore, fie, no,
That you have been kind, or so, your whore doth live
In Pict-hatch, Turnebole-streete.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Your whore lives there,
Well Servant leave me to myself a while,
Return anon, but bear this hope away,
It shall be with you, if I at all do stray.
Why here is right worldly friendship, ye are well met;
O men! what are you? why is our poor sex
Still made the disgraced subjects, in these plays?
For vices, folly and inconstancy?
When were men looked into with such critical eyes
Of observation, many would be found
So full of gross and base corruption,
That none (Unless the Devil himself turned writer)
Could fain so badly, to express them truly;
Some wives that had a husband now like mine,
Would yield their honours up, to any man,
Far be it from my thoughts, O let me stand,
Thou God of marriage and chastity,
An honour to my sex, no injury,
Compel the virtue of my breast to yield,
It is not revenge for any wife, to stain
The nuptial bed, although she be yoked ill,
who falls, because her husband so hath done,
Cures not his wound, but in herself makes one.

div2.stage: Enter Ingen reading a letter, sits downe in a Chaire and stampes with his foote: to him a Seruant.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: who brought this Letter?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p:
A little Irish foot-boy, Sir, he stays without for an
answer.

div2.stage: Enter Maid like an Irish foot-boy with a dart, and gloues in bir pocket, and a handkercher.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Bid him come in Lord.
What deep dissemblers are these females, all,
How far unlike a friend, this Lady used me,
And here, how like one mad in love, she writes:
So bless me Heaven, but thou art the prettiest boy
That ever ran by a Horse, hast thou dwelt long
With thy fair Mistress?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I came but this morning, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: How fares thy Lady, boy?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Like to a turtle, that hath lost her mate,
Drooping she sits, her grief Sir cannot speak,
Had it a voice articulate, we should know
How, and for what she suffers; and perhaps,
(But it is unlikely) give her Comfort Sir,
Weeping she sits, and all the sound comes from her,
Is like the murmur of a silver Brooke,
Which her tears truly, would make there about her,
Sate she in any hollow continent.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Believe me boy, thou hast a passionate tong,
Lively expression, or thy memory
Hath carried thy lesson well away,
But wherefore mourns thy Lady?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Sir, you know,
And would to God I did not know myself,

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Ah alas, it cannot be for love to me,
When last I saw her she reviled me (boy)
With bitterest words, and wished me never more
To approach her sight, and for my marriage, now
I do sustain it, as a penance, due
To the desert, that made her banish me.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Sir, I dare swear, she did presume, no words
Nor dangers, had been powerful to restrain
Your coming to her, when she gave the charge -
But are you married truly?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Why my Boy?
Dost think I mock myself, I sent her gloves.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
The gloves she has returned you Sir by me,
And prays you give them to some other Lady
That you will deceive next, and be perjured to.
Sure you have wronged her Sir, she bad me tell you,
She never thought goodness dwelt in many men,
But what there was of goodness in the world,
she thought you had it all, but now she sees
The jewel she esteemed is counterfeit
That, you are but a common man, yourself,
A traitor to her, and her virtuous love;
That all men are betrayers and their breasts
As full of dangerous gulfs, as is the Sea,
Where any woman thinking to find Harbour,
She and her honour are precipitated
And never to be brought with safety off:
Ah alas my hapless Lady, desolate,
Distressed, forsaken Virgin.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Sure this Boy
Is of an excellent nature, who so newly
Taken to her service, feels his Mistress grief,
As he and they were old familiar friends,
Why weepest thou gentle Lad?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
who hath one tear,
And would not save it from all occasions,
From Brothers slaughters, and from mothers deaths
To spend it here, for my distressed Lady;
But Sir my Lady did command me beg
To see your wife, that I may bare to her
The sad report, what creature could make you
Untie the hand-fast plighted unto her.

div2.stage: Enter his Brother like a woman maskt. Ingen kisses her.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p:
Wife, wife, come forth-now Gentle boy, be judge
If such a face as this being paid with scorn
By her I did adore, had not full power
To make me marry.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
By the God of Love,
She is a fair Creature, but faith should be fairer.
My Lady, Gentle Mistress, one that thought
She had some interest in this Gentleman,
(who now is only yours) Commanded me
To kiss your white hand, and to sigh and weep,
And wish you that content she should have had
In the fruition of her Love you hold,
She bad me say, God give you joy, to both;
Yet this withal (if ye were married)
No-one, her foot-steps ever more should meet,
Nor see her face, but in a winding sheet.

sp.speaker: Brother.
sp.p:
Alas poor Lady, i'faith I pity her,
And, but to be in the same state, could forgo
Anything I possess, to ease her woe.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Love's blessing light upon thy gentle soul,
Men rail at women Mistress, but it is we
Are false and cruel, ten times more unkind,
You are smoother far, and of a softer mind:
Sir, I have one request more.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Gentle Lad, It must be one of a strange quality
That I deny thee, both thy form, and mind.
Inform me that thy nurture hath been better;
Than to betray thee to this present life.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
It is, that you would vouchsafe to entertain me,
My feet do tremble under me, to bear
My body back unto my uncouth Lady,
To assure her grief; what heart so hard, would owe
A tongue, to tell so sad a tale to her?
Alas, I dare not look upon her eyes,
Where wronged love, sits like the Basilisk,
And sure would kill me for my dire report,
Or rather should not I appear like death,
When every word I speak shot through her heart,
More mortally than his unsparing dart.

sp.speaker: Brother.
sp.p: Let me speak for the Boy.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
To what end (love?)
No, I will sue to him, to follow me,
Introth I love thy sweet condition,
And may live to inform thy Lady of thee;
Come in dry, dry thine eyes, respite thy woe:
The effects of causes, crown, or overthrow.

div2.stage: Enter Lo. Provd. Lo. Feesim. Wel-tri'd, Ma. Seldome, Widd. Bovld pinning in a Ruffe, Wife.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
S'light, what should be become of her, you swear
she past not forth of doors, and in the house she is not?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Did you not see her Princox?

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
This same Bawd has brought her letters from
some younger brother, and she is stole away.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Bawd, I defy you, indeed your Lordship thinks,
you may make Bawds of whom you please, I will take my oath
upon a book, since I met her in the necessary house in the
morning, I never set eye on her.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: She went not out of doors.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Sure she has an invisible ring.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Marry she is the honester woman, for some of their
rings are visible enough, the more shame for them, still say
aye, let the pond at Islington be searched: go to, there is more
have drowned themselves for love this year then you are aware of.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Pish, you are a fool.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: S'hart call him fool again.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: By this light and I will, as soon as ever you have showed me the Swaggerers.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Her clothes are all yonder my Lord.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: And even those same she had on today.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Madam where is your Husband?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Rid into the Country.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: On my conscience, rid into France with your sister.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Away, away for shame.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Why, I hope she is not the first Lady that has run
away with other women's husbands.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: It may be she has stolen out to see a play.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Who should go with her, man?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Upon my life you will hear on her at Master Ingen's
house, some love past betwixt them, and we heard that he
was married today, to another.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: S'hart, I will go see.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Come to the Swaggerers.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Mercy upon me, a man or a - Lord now?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Here is a coil, with a Lord and his sister.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Princox, hast not thou pined in that Ruff yet, ah!
how thou fumblest.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Troth Madam, I was never brought up to it, it is
Chamber-maids work, and I have ever lived Gentlewoman.
And been used accordingly.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
She is a rare wife believe it Sir, were all such,
We never should have false inheritors.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
Pish friend, there is no woman in the world
Can hold out in the end, If youth, shape, wit,
Met in one subject, do assault her aptly,
For failing once, you must not faint but try
Another way, the path of women's minds
Are crooked, and diverse, they have by-ways
To lead you to the Palace of their pleasures,
And you must woo discreetly; first observe
The disposition of her you attempt,
If she be sprightly, and heroical,
Possess her that you are valiant, and have spirit,
Talk nothing but of beating every man
That is your hindrance, though you do not do it,
Or dare not, it is no matter. Be she free
And of a liberal soul, give bounteously
To all the servants, let your angels fly
About the room, although you borrowed them.
If she be witty, so must your discourse
Get wit, what shift soever you make for it,
though it cost you all your land, and then a song
Or two is not amiss, although you buy them,
There is many in the Town will furnish you.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
But still I tell you, you must use her roughly,
Beat her face black and blue, take all her cloth's
And give them to some Punk, this will be ground
For me to work upon.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
All this I have done.
I have left her now, as bare, that should I die,
Her fortune (on my conscience) would be
To marry some Tobacco-man, she has nothing
But an old black-work waistcoat, which would serve
Exceeding well to fit in the shop and light
Pipes for the lousy Footmen (and sweet friend)
First here is a jewel to present her, then
Here is a Sonnet writ against myself,
Which as thine own thou shalt accost her with,
Farewell and happy success attend thee.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha.
Fairest, still wilt thou be true
To a man so false to thee?
Did he lend a Husbands due,
Thou didst owe him loyalty;
But will curses, wants and blows
Breed no change in thy white soul?
Be not a fool to thy first vows,
Since his breach, doth thy faith control,
No beauty else, could be so chaste,
Think not thou honourest women then,
Since by thy conscience, all disgraced,
Are robbed of the dear loves of men;
Then grant me my desire that vow to prove
A real husband, his adulterate love.
Tooke ever man more pains to be a Cuckold?
O! monstrous age where men themselves we see,
Study and pay for their own infamy.

div2.stage: Enter Ingen, Maid, Provdly, Brother like a woman, swords drawen.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Give me my sister, I will have her forth thy heart.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
No earthly Lord can pull her out of that,
Till he have plucked my heart first out, my Lord
Were it not inhospitable, I could wrong you here
In mine own house, I am so full of woe,
For your lost sister, that by all my joys
Hoped for in her, my heart weeps tears of blood,
A whiter virgin, and a worthier,
Had never creation: Loeda's Swan was black
To her virginity, and immaculate thoughts.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
Where hast thou hid her? give her me again,
For by the God of vengeance, be she lost,
The female hate shall spring betwixt our names,
Shall never die, while one of either house
Survives, our children shall at seven years old
Strike knives in one another.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Let Hell gape
And take me quick, if I know where she is,
But am so charged with sorrow for her loss,
Being the cause of it (as no doubt I am)
That I had rather fall upon my sword
Than breath a minute longer.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p: O sir! hold.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
Thou shalt not need, I have a sword to bathe
In thy false blood, inhumane murderer.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Good Sir be pacified, I will go, I will run
Many a mile to find your sister out;
She never was so desperate of grace,
By violence to rob herself of life,
And so her soul in danger; comfort Sir,
She is but retired somewhere on my life.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Prithee let me alone -
Do I stand to defend that wretched life
That is in doubt of hers, here worthy Lord,
Behold a breast, framed of thy sisters love,
Hew it, for thou shalt strike but on a stock,
Since she is gone that was the cause it lived.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Out false dissembler, art not married?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
No, behold, it is my younger brother dressed,
A man, no woman, that hath gulled the world,
Intended for a happier event
Than this that followed, that she now is gone,
O fond experiments of simple man,
Fool to thy fate, since all thy project meant
But mirth, is now converted unto death.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
O do not burst me joy, that modesty
Would let me show myself to finish all.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
Nay, then thou hast my sister somewhere villain,
It is plain now, thou wilt steal thy marriage,
she is no match for thee, assure thyself.
If all the law in England, or my friends
Can cross it, it shall not be.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Would it were so well,
And that I knew the Lady to be safe.
Give me no ill words; Sir, this Boy and I
Will wander like two Pilgrims, till we find her:
If you do love her as you talk, do so:
The love or grief that is expressed in words,
Is sleight and easy, it is but shallow woe
That makes a noise, deepest waters stillest go;
I love her better than thy parents did,
Which is beyond a Brother.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Slave, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: Z'oones.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p: Kill him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
O hold; Sir, you dishonour much your brother,
To counsel him against hospitality,
To strike in his own house.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
You, Lord insolent, I will sight with you,
Take this, as a challenge, and set your time.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
Tomorrow morning Ingen,
It is that I covet, and provoke thee for.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Will you not strike him now?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
No, my good Boy
Is both discreet and just in his advice.
Thy glories are to last but for a day;
Give me thy hand, tomorrow morning thou shalt be no Lo.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Tomorrow noon, thou shalt not be at all.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Pish, why should you think so, have not I arms,
A soul as bold as yours, a sword as true:
I do not think your Honour in the field
Without your Lordships liveries will have odds.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Farewell, and let us have no excuses, pray.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
I warrant you, pray say your prayers tonight,
And bring no ink-horn with ye, to set your hand to
A satisfactory recantation.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
O wretched Maid, whose sword can I pray for?
But by the others loss, I must find death,
O odious brother, if he kill my love:
O bloody Love, if he should kill my brother;
Despair on both sides of my discontent,
Tells me no safety rests but to prevent.

div2.stage: Enter Widdovv and Bovld like Princox.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What is a clock Princox?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Bed-time if it please you Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come, undress me, would God had made me a man.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Why, Madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Because I would have been in bed as soon as they,
we are so long unpinning and unlacing.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p:
Yet many of us Madam are quickly undone sometime,
but herein we have the advantage of men, though
they can be a bed sooner than we, it is a great while when
they are a bed ere they can get up.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Indeed if they be well laid Princox, one cannot get
them up again in haste.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
O God Madam, how mean you that, I hope
you know, ill things taken into a Gentlewoman's ears, are
the quick corruptors of maiden modesty, I would be loath
to continue in any service unfit for my virgin estate, or where
the world should take any notice of light behaviour in the
Lady I follow: for Madam, the main point of chastity in
a Lady, is to build the rock of a good opinion amongst the
people by circumstances, and a fair show she must make, Si,
von caste, tamen caute Madam, and though wit be a wanton
Madam: yet I beseech your Lady-ship for your own credit
and mine, let the bridle of judgment be always in the
chaps of it to give it head, or restrain it, according as time
and place shall be convenient.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Precise and learned Princox, dost not thou go to
Black-fryers.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Most frequently Madam, unworthy vessel that
I am to partake or retain any of the delicious dew, that is
there distilled.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
But why shouldst thou ask me what I meant even
now, I tell thee there is nothing uttered that carries a double
sense, one good, one bad, but if the hearer apply it to the
worst, the fault lies in his or her corrupt understanding, not
in the speaker, for to answer your latin: prauis omnia praua,
believe me wench, if ill come into my fancy, I will purge
it by speech, the less will remain within: a pox of these
nice mouthed creatures, I have seen a narrow pair of lips utter
as broad a tail, as can be bought for money; Indeed an
ill tale unuttered, is like a maggot in a nut, it spoils the
whitest kernel.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: You speak most intelligently Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Hast not done yet? thou art an old fumbler I perceive:
methinks thou dost not do things like a woman.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Madam, I do my endeavour, and the best can
do no more, they that could do better, it may be would
not, and then it were all one, but rather than be a burthen
to your Lady-ship, I protest sincerely, I would beg my bread,
therefore I beseech you Madam to hold me excused, and
let my good will stand for the action.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Let thy good will stand for the action? If good will
would do it, there is many a Lady in this Land would be
content with her old Lord, and thou canst not be a burthen
to me, without thou lie upon me, and that were preposterous
in thy sex; take no exceptions at what I say, remember you
said stand even now, there was a word for one of your coat
indeed.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
I swear Madam, you are very merry, God send
you good luck, has your Ladyship no waters, that you use at
bed-time?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No introth, Princox.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: No Complexion?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: None but mine own I swear, didst thou ever use any?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
No indeed Madam: now and then a piece of
scarlet, or so; a little white and red Cerise; but in troth Madam,
I have an excellent receipt for a night masque, as ever
you heard.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Bores grease one ounce, Jordan Almonds blanched
and ground a quart, red Rose-water, half a pint,
Mares urine, newly covered, half a score drops.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Faugh, no more of thy medicine, if thou lovest me,
few of our Knights errant, when they meet a fair Lady
arrant, in a morning, would think her face had lain so plastered
all night: thou hast had some Apothecary to thy sweet
heart: but leaving this face physic, for (by my troth) it may
make others have good ones; but it makes me make a scurvy
one. Which of all the Gallants in the Town wouldst
thou make a husband of, if thou mightst have him for thy
choosing?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
In troth Madam, but you will say I speak blindly,
but let my love stand a side.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
I think it not fit indeed your love should stand in the
middle.

sp.speaker: Boul.
sp.p:
I say Master Bould; O, do but mark him Madam,
his leg, his hand, his body, and all his members stand in print.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Out upon thee Princox; no, methinnks Well-tried is a
handsome fellow, I like not these starched Gallants: masculine
faces, and masculine gestures please me best.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: How like you Master Pert?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Fie upon him, when he is in his scarlet clothes, he
looks like a man of wax, and I had as lieve have a dog a
wax, I do not think but he lies in a case a nights, he walks
as if he were made of gins, as if nature had wrought him in
a frame, I have seen him sit discontented a whole play, because
one of the pearls of his band was fallen (out of his
reach) to order again.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Why? Bould Madam is clean contrary.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Aye but that is as ill, each extreme, is alike vicious; his
careful carelessness is his study, he spends as much time to
make himself slovenly, as the other to be spruce, his garters
hang ever on the calves of his legs, his doublet unbuttoned,
and his points untrussed, his hair in his eyes like a drunkard, and
his hat worn on his hinder part of his head, as if he cared
more for his memory, than his wit: makes him look as if he
were distracted; Princox, I would have you lie with me, I
do not love to lie alone.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: With all my heart Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Are you clean skinned?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Clean skinned Madam? there is a question, do you
think I have the itch? I am an English-woman, I protest, I
scorn the motion.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Nay prithee Princox be not angry, it is a sign of honesty
I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Faith Madam I think it is but simple honesty that
dwells at the sign of the scab.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Well, well, come to bed, and we will talk further of
all these matters.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Fortune, I thank thee, I will owe thee eyes.
For this good turn, now is she mine indeed,
Thou hast given me that success my project hoped
Of, false disguise that hast been true to me,
And now be Bould, that thou mayst welcome be.

div2.stage: Enter Whoore-bang, Bots, Teare-chops, Spil-blovd and Dravver: seuerall patches on their faces.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p:
Dam-me, we will have more wine, sirrah, or we will down
into the Seller, and drown thee in a Butt of Malmesey,
and hew all the Hogs-heads in pieces.

sp.speaker: Whoore.
sp.p:
Hang him rogue, shall he die as honourably as the
Duke of Clarence; by this flesh let us have wine, or I will cut
thy head off, have it roasted and eaten in Pie-corner next
Bartholmew-tide.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I beseech you consider where you
are, Turne-bole street, a civil place, do not disturb a number
a poor Gentlewomen, Master Whoore-band, Master: Bots,
Master: Teare-chops, and Master: Spill-bloud, the Watch are abroad.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p:
The Watch? why you rogue, are not we Kings of
Turne-bole?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p:
Yes marry are ye, Sir, for my part, if you will be
quiet, I will have a sign made of ye, and it shall be called the
four Kings of Turne-bole.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Will you fetch us wine?

sp.speaker: Whoore.
sp.p: And a whore (sirrah)

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p:
Why what do ye think of me, am I an Infidel, a
Turk, a Pagan, a Saracen, I have been at Besse Turnups,
and she swears all the Gentlewomen went to see a Play at
the Fortune, and are not come in yet, and she believes they
sup with the Players.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p:
Dam-me, we must kill all those rogues, we shall never
keep a whore honest for them.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Go your ways, sirrah, we will have but a gallon a
piece, and an ounce of Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I beseech you, let it be but pottles.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p: S'hart you rogue?

sp.speaker: Whoore.
sp.p: Master Well-tri'd, welcome as my soul.

div2.stage: Enter Dravver with Wine, Plate, and Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Noble Lad, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p: As welcome, as the Tobacco and the Wine Boy.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: Dam-me thou art.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p:
Bless me (save you Gent.) They have not one
face among them. I could wish myself well from them, I
would I had put out something upon my return, I had as
lieve be at the Barmuthoes.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Pray welcome this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p: Is he valiant?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Faith he is a little faulty that way: somewhat of a
bashful and backward nature, yet I have brought him
amongst you, because he hath a great desire to be fleshed.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: Yes faith Sir, I have a great desire to be fleshed: now Mister Well-tri'd said, he would bring me to the only flesh-mongers in the town.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Sir, he cannot endure the sight of steel.

sp.speaker: Whor.
sp.p: Not steel? zoones.

div2.stage: Claps his Sword ore the Table.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: Now I am going.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.p: Here is to you sir, I will fetch you again with a cup of sack.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: I pledge you sir, and begin to you in a cup of Claret:

sp.speaker: Wellt.
sp.p:
Hark you my Lo: what will you say, if I make you
beat all these out of the room?

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p:
What will I say? why I say it is impossible, it is not in
mortal man.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Well drink apace, if any brave you, out brave him,
I will second you, they are a Company of cowards believe me.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: By this light I would they were else, if I thought so, I would be upon the Jack of one of them instantly, that same little Damn-me. But Mister Wel-tri'd, if they be not very valiant or dare not fight, how come they by such Cuts and gashes, and such broken faces?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
Why their whores strike them with Cans, and glasses,
and quart pots, if they have nothing by them, they strike
them with the Pox, and you know that will lay ones nose as
flat as a basket hilt Dagger.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Well let me alone.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: This bully dares not drink.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Dare I not Sir.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Well said, speak to him man.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: You had best try me Sir.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p:
We four will drink four healths to four of the
seven deadly sins, Pride, Drunkenness, wrath and Lechery.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: I will pledge them, and I thank you, I know them all, here is one.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Which of the sins?

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: By my troth even to Pride.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
Why well said, and in this do not you only pledge
your Mistress health, but all the women's in the world.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p:
So now, this little Cup to Wrath, because he and I
are strangers.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: Brave boy, Dam me he shall be a Roarer.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Dam me, I will be a roarer, or it shall cost me a fall.

sp.speaker: Botts.
sp.p: The next place that falls, pray let him have it.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p:
Well, I have two of my healths to drink yet, Lechery
and Drunkenness which even shall go together.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Why how now my Lord, a Moralist?

sp.speaker: Botts.
sp.p: Dame me, art thou a Lo: what virtues hast thou?

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p:
Virtues? enough to keep ever a Dam me Company
in England, methinks you should think it virtue enough
to be a Lord.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p:
Will not you pledge these healths Master Weltride?
we will have no observers.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Why, Mounser Whore-bang? I am no play maker,
and for pledging your healths, I love none of the four,
you drank to so well.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p: Zoones you shall pledge me this.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Shall I?

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p:
What is the matter, dost hear Master Wel-trid, use
thine own discretion, if thou wilt not pledge him, say so?
and let me see, if ever a Dam me of them all, will force thee.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p:
Puff, will your Lordship take any Tobacco? you
Lord, with the white face?

sp.speaker: Botts.
sp.p: Heart he cannot put it through his nose.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p:
Faith you have never a nose to put it through, the heart
blow your face sirrah.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: You will pledge me Sir?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Indeed I will not.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p:
Dam me he shall not then.
Tear, Lord, use your own words, Dam me is mine,
I am known by it all the town over, do ye hear?

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: It is as free for me as you, do ye hear Patch?

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: I have paid more for it.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Nay I will bear him witness in a truth, his soul lies
for it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p:
Wel-tri'd, you are grown proud since you got
good Clothes, and have followed your Lord.

sp.speaker: Whoore.
sp.p: I have known you lousy, Wel-trid,

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Roarer you lie.

div2.stage: Draw and fight, throw pots and stooles.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: O Jesu.

sp.speaker: All Sw.
sp.p:
Zoones cleave or be cleft: pell mell, slash arms
and legs.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Heart let me alone with them.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Why now thou art a worthy wight, indeed a Lord
a Lorn.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: I am a mad man, look is not that one of their heads?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Fie no my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p:
Dam me but it is, I would not wish you to cross me
a purpose, if you have anything to say to me, so, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
O brave Lord, many a roarer thus is made by wine:
come it is one of their heads my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p:
Why so then, I will have my humour, if you love me,
let us go break windows somewhere.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Drawer, take your plate, for the reckoning there is
some of their cloaks: I will be no shot-log to such.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p:
Gods blessing on your heart, for thus ridding the
house of them.

div2.stage: Enter Widdovv vndrest, a sword in her hand, and Bovld in his shirt, as started from bed.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Uncivil man, if I should take thy life,
It were not to be weighed with thy attempt:
Thou hast for ever lost me.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Madam, why?
Can love beget loss? Do I covet you
Unlawfully? Am I an unfit man
To make an husband of? Send for a Priest,
First consummate the match, and then to bed
Without more trouble.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, I will not do it.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Why you confessed to me as you are Gentlewoman,
I was the man your heart did most affect:
That you did dote upon my mind and body.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
So, by the sacred and inviolate knot
Of marriage, I do, but will not wed thee.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Why yet enjoy me now. Consider Lady,
That little, but blessed time, I was in bed,
Although I lay as by my sisters side,
The world is apt to censure otherwise:
So it is necessity that we marry now.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Pish, I regard not (at a straw) the world:
Fame from the tongues of men doth injury
Oftener than Justice: and as conscience
Only makes guilty persons, not report:
(For show we clear as springs unto the world,
If our own knowledge do not make us so,
That is no satisfaction to ourselves,)
So stand we never so leprous to men's eye,
It cannot hurt heart-known integrity.
You have trusted to that fond opinion,
This is the way to have a widowhood,
By getting to her bed: Alas young man,
Shouldst thou thyself tell thy companions
Thou hadst dishonoured me (as you men have tongues
Forked and venomed against our subject sex)
It should not move me, that know it is not so:
Therefore depart, Truth be my virtuous shield.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Few widows would do thus.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: All modest, would.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
To be in bed and in possession
Even of the mark I aimed at, and go off
Foiled and disgraced, come, come, you will laugh at me
Behind my back, publish I wanted spirit,
And mock me to the Ladies, call me child,
Say you denied me but to try the heate
And zeal of my affection toward you,
Then clapped up with a rime, as for example.
He coldly loves, retires, for one vain trial,
For we are yielding, when we make denial.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Servant I make no question, from this time
You will hold a more reverent opinion
Of some that wear long coats, and it is my pride,
To assure you that there are amongst us good:
And with this continence, if you go away,
I will be so far from thinking it defect,
That I will hold you worthiest of men.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
S'hart, I am Tantalus, my longed for fruit
Bobs at my lips, yet still it shrinks from me.
Have not I that, which men say never fails
To overcome any? opportunity?
Come, come, I am too cold in my assault.
By all the virtues, that yet ever were
In man, or woman, I with reverence
Do love thee Lady, but will be no fool
To let occasion slip, her fore-top from me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
You will fail this way too, upon my knees
I do desire thee to preserve thy virtues,
And with my tears my honour; it is as bad
To lose our worths to them, or to deceive
who have held worthy opinions of us,
As to betray trust: all this I implore
For thine own sake, not mine, as for myself,
If thou beest violent, by this stupid night,
And all the mischiefs her dark womb hath bred,
I will raise the house, I will cry a rape.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p:
I hope you will not hang me, that were murther Lady,
A greater sin, than lying with me sure.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Come, flatter not yourself with argument,
I will exclaim; the law hangs you, not I,
Or if I did, I had rather far confound
The dearest body in the world to me,
Than that, that body, should confound my soul.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Your soul, alas Mistress, are you so fond
To think her general destruction
Can be procured by such a natural act,
Which beasts are born to and have privilege in?
Fie, fie, if this could be, far happier
Are sensitive souls in their creation
Than man the prince of creatures, think you Heaven
Regards such mortal deeds, or punisheth
Those acts, for which he hath ordained us?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
You argue like an Atheist, man is never
The prince of creatures, as you call him now,
But in his reason, fail that, he is worse
Than Horse, or Dog, or beasts of wilderness,
And it is that reason teacheth us to do
Our actions unlike them: then that which you
Termed in them a privilege beyond us,
The baseness of their being doth express,
Compared to ours, Horses, Bulls, and Swine,
Do leap their Dams, because man does not so,
Shall we conclude his making happiless?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
You put me down, yet will not put me down,
I am too gentle, some of you I have heard,
Love not these words but force, to have it done
As they sing prick-song, even at the first sight.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go to, keep off, by Heaven and Earth, I will call else.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: How if nobody hear you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
If they do not,
I will kill you with mine own hand, never stare,
Or failing that fall on this sword myself.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
O widow wonderful, if thou beest not honest.
Now God forgive my mother and my sisters.
Think but how finely Madam undiscovered
For ever you and I, might live all day your Gentlewoman
To do you service, but all night your man
To do you service, newness of the trick,
If nothing else might stir ye.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
It is a stale one
And was done in the Fleete ten years ago,
Will you begone? the door is open for you.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Let me but tarry till the morning Madam,
To send for clothes, shall I go naked home.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
It is best time now, it is but one a clock,
And you may go unseen, I swear by Heaven,
I would spend all the night to sit and talk with ye,
If I durst trust you, I do love you so,
My blood forsakes my heart now you depart.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: S'hart, will you marry me hereafter then?

sp.speaker: Wid.
Bould.
sp.p:
Why so? these women are the arrantest Jugglers in
the World, the wry-legged fellow is an Ass to them. Well I
must have this widow, whatever come of it: Faith she has
turned me out of her service very barely, hark, what is here, music.

div2.stage: Enter Svbtle with a paper, and his Boy with a cloake.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Rise Lady Mistress, rise:
The night hath tedious been,
No sleep hath fallen into my eyes,
Nor slumbers made me sin.
Is not she a Saint then say,
Thought of whom keeps sin away?
Rise Madam, rise and give me light,
Whom darkness still will cover,
And ignorance darker than night,
Till thou smile on thy lover;
All want day till thy beauty rise,
For the gray morn breaks from thine eyes.
Now sing it sirrah.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
S'foote, who is this? young Master Bould? God save
you, you are an early stirrer.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
You say true Master Subtle, I have been early
up, but as God help me, I was never the never.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Where have you been Sir?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: What is that to you Sir? at a woman's labour.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Very good: I never took you for a man Mid-wife
before.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
The troth is, I have been up all night at dice, and
lost my clothes, good morrow Master Subtle, pray God the
Watch be broke up: I thank you for my Music:

sp.speaker: Subt:
sp.p:
It is palpable by this air, her husband being abroad,
Bould has lain with her, and is now conveyed out of doors.
Is this the Lady Perfect with a pox? The truth is, her virtuous
chastity, began to make me make a miracle of her,
still holding out to me, notwithstanding her husbands most
barbarous usage of her, but now indeed it is no marvel
since another possesses her. Well Madam, I will go find out
your Cuckold, I will be revenged on you and tell a tale
Shall tickle him, this is a cheat in love,
Not to be borne, another to be guile
Me of the game, I played for all this while.

div2.stage: Enter Weltri'd, and Bovld puting on his doublet, Fee-simple on a bed, as in Bould's chamber.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
You see, we made bould with your lodging, indeed,
I did assure myself, you were fast for this night.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: But how the Deuill came this fool in your company?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
S'foote man, I carried him last night among the
Roarers, to flesh him, and by this light he got drunk, and
beat them all.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Why then he can endure the sight of a drawn
sword now?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
O God Sir, I think in my conscience, he will eat
steel shortly, I know not how his conversion will hold
after this sleep, but in an hour or two (last night) he was
grown such a little dam-me, that I protest, I was afraid of
the spirit, that I myself had raised in him: but this other
matter of your expulsion thus mads me to the heart; Were
you in bed with her?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: In bed by Heaven.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
I will be hanged, if you were not busy too soon, you
should have let her slept first.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Z'oones man, she put her hands to my breasts, and
swore I was no maid, now I being eager to prove her words
true, took that hint, and would violently have thrust her
hand lower, when her thought being swifter than my
strength, made her no sooner imagine that she was betrayed,
but she leaps out of the bed, whips me down a sword that
hung by, and as, if fortitude and justice had met to assist
her, spite of all argument fair or foul she forced me away.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
But is it possible thou shouldest have no more wit,
wouldst thou come away upon any terms, but sure ones,
having night, her chamber and herself naked in thine
arms? By that light, if I had a son of fourteen whom I had
helped thus far, that had served me so, I would breech him.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: S'hart, what would you have me done?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Have done? done, done twice at least.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Have played Tarquin and ravished her.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Pish, Tarquin was a block-head, if he had had any
wit and could have spoke, Lucrece had never been ravished,
she would have yielded, I warrant thee, and so will any woman

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
I was such an erroneous heretic to love, and
women, as thou art, till now.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
God's precious, it makes me mad, when I think
of it: was there ever such an obscured trick? now will she abuse
thee horribly, say thou art a faint-hearted fellow, a
milk-sop and I know not what, as indeed thou art.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Z'oones, would you had been in my place.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Z'oones, I would I had, I would have so jumbled her
honesty: wouldst thou be held out at staves end with words?
dost not thou know a widow is a weak vessel, and is easily
cast if you close.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Weltri'd, you deal unfriendly.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: By this light I shall blush to be seen in thy company.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Pray leave my chamber.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Pox upon your chamber,
I care not for your chamber, nor yourself
More than you care for me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: S'blood I as little for you.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Why fare you well.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p:
Why, fare-well you. Weltri'd, I prithee stay,
Thou knowest I love thee.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
S'hart, I love you as well; but for my spleen, or
choler I think, I have as much as you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p:
Well friend, this is the business you must do for me,
Repair unto the widow, where give out,
Tomorrow morn, I shall be married,
Invite her to the wedding, I have a trick,
To put upon this Lord too, whom I made
My instrument to prefer me.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
What shall follow,
I will not ask, because I mean to see it.
The jars betwixt friends, still keeps their friendship sweet.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Why Weltri'd, you rogue, what is that a vision?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Why how now my Lord? who do you call rogue?
the Gentleman you name is my friend, if you were wise I
should be angry.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Angry with me? why dam me Sir, and you be;
Cut with your sword, it is not with me I tell you
As it was yesterday, I am fleshed man, I.
Have you anything to say to me?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Nothing but this, how many do you think,
you have slain last night?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Why five, I never kill less.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
There was but four: my Lord, you had best provide
yourself and begone, three you have slain stark dead.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: You jest.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: It is most true, Weltri'd is fled.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Why let the Roarers meddle with me another time,
as for flying, I scorn it, I killed them like a man; when did you
ever see a Lord hang for anything? we may kill whom we
list, marry my conscience pricks me; ah plague a this drink,
what things it makes us do, I do no more remember this
now than a puppy-dog.
O bloody Lord that art bedaubed with gore,
Vain world adieu, for I will roar no more.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Nay stay my Lord, I did but try the tenderness
of your conscience, all this is nothing so, but to sweeten the
