tale (I have for you) I foretold you this feigned mischance.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Is it a tale belonging to the Widow?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: I think you are a witch.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: My grand-mother was suspected.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
The Widow has desired you by me to meet her
tomorrow morning at Church in some unknown disguise,
lest any suspect it, for quoth she.
Long hath he held me fast in his moist hand,
Therefore I will be his in nuptial band.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Bould, I have overtaken you to be my friend, I am
very wise now, and valiant, if this be not true, dam me Sir,
you are the son of a whore, and you lie, and I will make it
good with my sword.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
I am, whatever you please Sir, If it be not true, I will
go with you to the Church myself, your disguise I have
thought on; the Widow is your own . Come, leave your
fooling.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
If this be true, thou little Boy, Bould.
So true, as thou tellest to me,
Tomorrow morn when I have the Widow,
My dear friend shalt thou be.

div2.stage: Enter Maid like the foote-boy: Seldome with a couple of Serieants, Pits, Donner.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Sir, it is most true and in this shall you be
unlike to other Citizens that arrest
To undo Gentlemen: your clemency here
perchance saves two lives, one from the others sword,
The other from the Law's; this morn they fight,
And though your debtor be a Lord, yet should he
Miscarry, certainly your debt were lost.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p: Dost thou serve the Lord Proudly?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p:
Well, such a Boy as thou, is worth more money
than thy Lord owes me, it is not for the debt
I do arrest him, but to end this strife,
Which both may lose my money and his life.

div2.stage: Enter Lord Provdly with a riding rod.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
My Horse there, Z'oones I would not for the world
He should alight before me in the field,
My name and honour were for ever lost.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p:
Good morrow to your Honour, I do hear
Your Lordship this fair morning is to fight,
And for your honour: Did you never see
The Play, where the fat Knight hight Old-castle,
Did tell you truly what this honour was?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Why, how now good man flat-cap, what do ye lack?
who do you talk to, sirrah?

sp.speaker: 1. Serg.
sp.p: We arrest you.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Arrest me, rogue? I am a Lord ye curs, a Parliament
man.

sp.speaker: 2. Serg.
sp.p: Sir, we arrest you though.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: At whose suit?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p: At mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Why thou base rogue, did not I set thee up,
Having no stock, but thy fair shop and wife?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p: Into my house with him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Away with him, away with him.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
A plot, a trick by Heaven. See Ingens footboy, it is
by his Masters means, O coward, slave; I will put in bail, or
pay the debt.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Aye, aye, aye, we will talk with you within - thrust him in.

div2.stage: Enter Ingen looking on his sword and bending it, his brother like a Man.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
If I miscarry Franck, I prithee see
All my debts paid, about five hundred pounds
Will fully satisfy all men, and my land
And what I else possess, by natures right
And thy descent, Franck, I make freely thine.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p:
I know, you do not think I wish you dead
For all the benefit: besides, your spirit
So opposite to counsel, to avert
Your resolution, that I save my breath,
Which would be lost in vain, to expire and spend
Upon your foe if you fall under him.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Franck, I protest you shall do injury
Unto my foe, and much disturbance too
Unto my soul departing, die I here
Fairly, and on my single enemies sword,
If you should not let him go off untouched.
Now by the Master of thy life and mine,
I love thee Boy, beyond any example,
As well as thou dost me, but should I go
Thy second to the field, as thou dost mine,
And if thine enemy killed thee like a man,
I would desire, never to see him more,
But he should bear himself off with those wounds
He had received from thee, for that time safe,
And without persecution by the Law,
For what hap is our foes, might be our own ,
And no man's judgment, sits in Justice place,
But weighing other men's as his own case.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p:
He has the advantage of you being a Lord,
For should you kill him, you are sure to die,
And by some Lawyer with a golden tongue,
That cries for right, ten angels on his side;
Your daring meet him, called presumption:
But kill he you, he, and his noble friends
Have such a golden snaffle for the jaws
Of man, deuouring Pithagorean Law,
They will rein her stubborn chaps, even to her tail:
And though she have iron teeth to meaner men,
So master her, that who displeased her most,
She shall lie under like a tired jade,
For small boats on rough seas are quickly lost,
But ships ride safe, and cut what by they list.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Follow what may, I am resolved dear Brother,
This monster valour, that doth feed on men,
Groans in me for my reputation.
This charge I give thee too, If I do die,
Never to part from the young Boy, which late
I entertained, but love him for my sake:
And for my Mistress the Lady Honour,
Whom to deceive, I have deceived myself.
If she be dead, pray God I may give up
My life a sacrifice on her brothers sword;
But if thou livest to see her gentle brother,
If I be slain, tell her I died because
I had transgressed against her worthy love.
This sword is not well mounted, let us see thine.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Your staying Sir, is in vain, for my Lord Proudly,
Just at his taking horse to meet you here,
At Seldomes suit the Citizen, was arrested
Upon an action of two hundred pounds,
I saw it Sir, it is true.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
O, scurvy Lord,
It had been a cleanlier shift then this to have had
It hindered by command, he being a Lord,
But I will find him.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
You see, valiant Sir, I have got loose
For all your stratagem, O rogue are you there.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: Most ignoble Lord.

div2.stage: Ingen stabs Proud. in the left arme.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
Coward thou didst this
That I might be disabled for the fight,
Or that thou mightst have some excuse to shun me,
But it is my left arm, thou hast lighted on.
I have no second; here are three of you,
If all do murther me, your consciences
Will more then hang you, damn you; come prepare.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.p: Brother walk off, and take the boy away, is he hurt much?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Nothing or very little.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
I will bind your wound up first, your loss of blood
May sooner make you faint.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Ingen, thou art a worthy Gentleman, for this courtesy,
Go-too I will save thy life, come on Sir: hey,
I will cut your codpiece point Sir, with this thrust,
And then down goes your breeches.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Your Lordships merry
I had like to have spoiled your cutwork band.

div2.stage: Enter Maid like a foote-boy running, Brother after him, Maid kneeles betwixt'em.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
O Master, hold your hand, my Lord hold yours,
Or let your swords meet in this wretched breast,
Yet you are both well, what blood you have lost
Give it as for the injury you did, and now be friends,

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: S'hart, it is a loving rogue.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Kind Boy, stand up, it is, for thy wound he bleeds,
My wrong is yet unsatisfied.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Hence away it is a Sisters loss, that whets my sword.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p:
O stay, my Lord, behold your sister here
Bleeding by your hand Servant see your mistress
Turned to thy servant running by thy Horse,
Whose means it was to have prevented this, but all in vain.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p: O noble Lady.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: Most worthy pattern of all women kind.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
Ingen, I am satisfied, put up your sword.
Sister, you must with me, I have a husband
The Lord Fee-simple's father, old, but rich:
This Gentleman is no match for you; kneel not,
That portion of yours, I have consumed,
Thus marrying, you shall never come to want.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
O! sweet my Lord, my brother do not force me,
To break my faith or to a loathed bed.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Force you, he shall not, brother bear her hence,
She is my wife, and thou shalt find my cause
Ten times improved now.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: O, have at you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Hold, hold for heaven's sake, was ever wretched Lady
Put to this hazard? Sir, let me speak
But one word with him, and I will go with you,
And undergo, what ever you command.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
Do it quickly, for I love no whispering,
It is strange to see you Madam with a sword,
You should have come hither in your Ladies clothes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Well, as you please my Lord, you are witness,
whatsoever before
Hath past betwixt us: thus I do undo.
Were not I mad, to think thou couldst love me
That wouldst have slain my Brother?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Sayst true sister.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
O thou fair creature! wilt thou be as false as other
Ladies?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Thou art my example,
I will kiss thee once, farewell for ever, come my Lord, now
Match me, with whom you please, a tumbler.
I must do this, else had they fought again.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Mine own best Sister, farewell Mister Ingen.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p:
O ancient truth to be denied of no man,
An Eel by the tail is held surer than a woman.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: She is not to be cast.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p:
It cannot be: had you a wife, and I were in your
case.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
I would be hanged even at the chamber door
Where I attempted, but I will lay her flat.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Why tell me truly, would it please you best,
To have her remain chaste, or conquered.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
O friend it would do me good at the heart
To have her overcome, she does so brag
And stand upon her chastity forsooth.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Why then in plain terms Sir, the fort is mine,
Your wife has yielded, up-tails is her song,
The deed is done, come, now, be merry man.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
Is the deed done indeed? come, come, you jest,
Has my wife yielded? is uptails her song?
Faith come, in prose, how got you to the matter first, ha.
Pish, you are so bashful now.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Why, by my troth I will tell you, because you are my
friend, otherwise you must note it is a great hurt to the art
of whoremastery to discouer, besides the skill was never
mine or the price.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Very good, on sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
At the first she was horrible stiff against me, then
Sir I took her by the hand, which I kissed.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
And I called her pretty Rogue, and I thrust my finger
betwixt her breasts, and I made lips; at last, I pulled her
by the chin to me, and I kissed her.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Hum, very good.

sp.speaker: Subt.
Hus.
sp.p: Aye that was very good, what said she to you then sir?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Nay, I went on. First quoth I, think how he hath
used you, left you no means, given all your clothes to his
Punks, struck you, turned your gray eyes into black ones,
but yet -

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: A pretty conceit.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Quoth I, these things are nothing in the Rascal,
think but what a base Whoremaster, the Rascal is.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Did you call me Rascal so often are you sure.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Yes, and oftener, for said I, none comes amiss to
the rogue, I have known him quoth I, do three lousy beggars
under hedges in the riding of ten mile, and I swore
this too.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: It was very well, but you did lie. On I pray.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p:
Pish, one must lie a little, now sir by this time she
began to kiss some what more openly, and familiarly, her
resistance began to slacken, and my assault began to stiffen,
the more her Bulwark decayed, the more my battery fortified,
at last sir, a little fumbling being past to make the Conquest
more difficult, she perceiving my readiness mounted,
falls me flat upon her back, cries me out aloud
Alas I yield use me not roughly friend,
My sort, that like Troy town, ten years hath stood
Besieged and shot at did remain unwon:
But now it is conquered. So the deed was done.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: Then came the hottest service. Forward with your tale sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: Nay Cætera, quis nescit, lassi requieuimus ambo: Proueniant medii sic mihi sæpe dies.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p:
Which is as much to say: I am a Cuckold, in all Languages,
but sure it is not so, It is impossible my wife should
yield.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p:
Hoyday, even now, it was impossible she should hold
out, and now it is impossible she should yield, stay you but
here and be an ear witness to what follows, I will fetch your
wife. - I know he will not stay.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p:
Good faith Sir but he will. I do suspect some knavery
in this.
Here will I hide myself, when thought as gone,
If they do aught unfitting I will call
Witness, and straight way sue a divorce.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p:
I knew he would not stay. Now noble Mistress,
I claim your promise.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What was that good servant

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: That you would lie with me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
If with any man,
But prithee first consider with thyself
If I should yield to thee, what a load thy Conscience
Would bear about it, for I wish quick thunder
May strike me, If I yet have lost the truth,
Or whiteness of the hand I gave in Church,
And it will not be, thy happiness (as thou thinkst)
That thou alone shouldst make a woman fall,
That did resist all else, but to thy soul
A bitter Corrosive, that thou didst stain,
Virtue that else had stood immaculate,
Nor speak I this, as yielding unto thee,
For it is not in thy power, wert thou the sweetest
Of natures Children, and the happiest,
To conquer me, nor in mine own to yield,
And thus it is with every pious wife.
Thy daily railing at my absent Husband
Makes me endure thee worse, for let him do
The most preposterous ill relishing things
To me, they seem good, since my Husband does them,
Nor am I to revenge or govern him,
And thus it should be with all virtuous Wives.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p:
Pox on this virtue and this chastity,
Do you know fair Mistress, a young Gentleman
About this town called Bould, where did he lie
Last night, sweet Mistress, O, O, are you catched,
I saw him slip out of the house this morn,
As naked as this truth, and for this cause
I have told your Husband that you yielded to me,
And he I warrant you, will blaze it thoroughly,
As good do now then as be thought to do.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
No, it will not be yet, thou injurious man,
How wilt thou right me in my Husbands thoughts,
That on a false surmise, and spite hast told,
A tale to breed incurable discontent?
Bould was that old wench that did serve the Widow,
and thinking by this way to gain her love
Missed of his purpose, and was thus cashiered,
Nor cares she to proclaim it to the world.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p:
Zoons, I have wronged you Mistress, On my knees
I ask you pardon, and will never more,
Attempt your purity, but neglect all things
Till that foul wrong I have bred in your Knight
I have expelled, and set your loves aright.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p:
Which now is done already, Madam, wife,
Upon my knees, with weeping eyes, heau'd hands,
I ask thy pardon, O sweet virtuous creature,
I prithee break my head.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Rise, rise, Sir pray:
You have done no wrong to me, at least I think so;
Heaven hath prevented all my injury,
I do forgive and marry you a new.
Come, we are all invited to the weddings,
The Lady Honour to the old rich Count.
Young Bould unto another Gentlewoman,
We and the Widow are invited thither,
Embrace and love, henceforth more really,
Not so like worldlings.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
Here then ends all strife
Thus false friends are made true, by a true wife.

div2.stage: Enter old Covnt wrapt in furs, the Ladie Honor drest like a Bride, the Lord Provd. Wel-trid, Bovld, leading Fee-simple like a Ladie masqu'd, Hvsband, Wife, Svbtle with a letter, Widdovv, to themBrother, Seldom, and his wife.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p:
Health and all joy unto this fair assembly,
My brother, who last tide is gone for France,
A branch of willow feathering his hat,
Bad me salute you Lady, and present you
With this same letter written in his blood,
He prays no man, for his fake evermore
To credit woman, nor no Lady ever
To believe man, so either sex shall rest
uninjured by the other, this is all, and this I have delivered.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: aye and well, you pronounce rarely, did you never play?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p: Yes, that I have, the fool, as some Lords do.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Set forward there.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O, O, O, a pox on this cold.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: A cold on this pox you might say, I am afeared.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
How full of ghastly wounds this letter shows,
O, O.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Look to my sister.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: S'hart the Lady swoons.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Strong water there.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: If strong breath would recover her, I am for her.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Alas good Lady, hum, hum hum.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: He has set her again with coughing.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Convey me to my bed send for a Priest
And a Physician, your Bride I fear,
In stead of Epithalamions shall need
A Dirge, or Epitaph, O lead me in,
My body dies for my soul's perjured sin.

div2.stage: Exit. Maid, Grace, Wife, Husb. Subtle.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Hymen comes towards us in a mourning robe.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: I hope friend, we shall have the better day.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: I will fetch the Parson and Physician

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p: They are both ready for you.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Madam, this is the Gentlewoman.
who something bashful does desire your pardon, that she
Does not unmask.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Good Master Wel-tri'd, I would not buy her face,
and for her manners if they were worse, they shall not displease
me.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: I thank your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Look, how the old Ass my father stands, he looks
like the Bear in the play, he has killed the Lady with his very
sight as God help me, I have the most to do to forbear
unmasking me, that I might tell him his own , as can be.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Fie, by no means.
The Widow comes towards you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O, O, O, O.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Servant, God give you joy, and Gentlewoman,
Or Lady as full joy, I wish to you,
Nor doubt that I will hinder you, your love,
But here am come to do all courtesy
To your fair self, and husband that shall be.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: I thank you heartily.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: S'hart, speak smaller man.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: I thank you heartily.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: You are going to this great to Mister Bould, um, um, um.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Not to your couching gear my Lord, though I
be not so old, or rich as your Lordship, yet I love a young
wench as well.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
As well, as my Lord, nay by my faith, that you do
not, love a young wench as well as he, I wonder you will be
unmannerly to say so.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Faith Master Wel-tri'd, troth is I love them well,
but they love not me, vm, vm, vm, you see, what ill luck, I
have with them, vmp, vmp, vmp, a pox on this cold still say I.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Where got you this cold my Lord? it can get in
nowhere that I can see, but at your nostrils, or eyes, all the other
parts are so barricadoed with fur.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
It got in at his eyes, and made that bird-lime there
where cupids wings do hang entangled.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Is this your wife, that (vm, vm, vm) shall be, Master.
Bould, I will be so bould as kiss her.

div2.stage: Count. sits in a chaire and fals a sleepe.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Sir, forbear, I have one bould enough to kiss my lips, O old coxcomb, kiss thine own natural son, it is worse than a Justices lying with his own daughter, but Mister Wel-tri'd when will the Widow break this matter to me?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
Not till the very close of all, she dissembles it yet,
because my Lord your Father is here, and her other suitor
Bould.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: That is all one, he is on the plot on my side:

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
It is needless Master Bould, but I will do
Anything you require to satisfy you,
Why should you doubt, I will forbid the banes,
For so your friend, here told me? I should rather
Doubt that you will not marry.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p:
Madam by heaven, as fully I am resolved to marry now,
And will too, if you do not hinder it,
As ever lover was, only because
The World has taken notice of some passage
Betwixt you and me, and then to satisfy
My sweet heart here, who poor soul is a feared,
To have some public disgrace put upon her,
I do require some small thing at your hands.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Well, I will do it, and this profess besides,
Married, you shall as welcome be to me
As mine own brother, and yourself fair Lady,
Even as myself, both to my board, and bed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Ah, ah, how like you that?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Now she begins, abundant thanks unto your widowhood.
Z'oones my Fathers asleep on his wedding day,
I wondered where his cough was all this while.

div2.stage: Enter Ingen like a Doctor: A Parson, Brother, Provdly, Seldome, Mris. Seld. Hvsband, Wife, and Svbtle.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.p:
I pray forbear the chamber, noise does hurt her.
Her sickness I guess rather of the mind
Than of her body, for her pulse beats well,
Her vital functions not decayed a whit,
But have their natural life and operation.
My Lord, be cheered, I have an ingredient about me,
Shall make her well I doubt not.
In Master Parson, it shall be yours I pray,
The soul's Physician should have still the way.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How cheers she pray?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: In troth exceeding ill.

sp.speaker: Ms. Seld.
sp.p:
A very weak woman indeed she is, and surely
I think cannot scape it.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Did you mark how she eyed the Physician?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O God aye, she is very loath to die.

sp.speaker: Ms. Seld.
sp.p: Aye that is the better sign, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
And when the Parson came to her, she turned away,
And still let the Physician hold her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
But see what thought the Bridegroom takes,
my conscience knows now, this is a most preposterous
match, yet for the commodity, we wink at all inconveniency.
My Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Vmp, vmp, vmp, I beshrew you for waking of me,
now shall I have such a fit of coughing, hum, hum -

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
O hapless wife, that shall have thee, that either
must let thee sleep continually, or be kept waking herself
by the cough.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
You have a proper Gentleman to your son, my
Lord, he were fitter for this young Lady than you.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: do ye mark that again?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: O sweet widow.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He a wife, he a fool's head of his own .

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: No, of my Fathers.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What should he do with a vmp, vmp?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
What with a cough? why he would spit, and that is
more than you can do.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Your bride my Lord is dead.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Marry, even God be with her, grief will not
help it, vmp, vmp, vmp.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p: A most excellent spouse.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
How fares she Mister Doctor. Zounds, what is here
Bould, Widow, Well-tried, Fee-simple, hoy-day.
Husband, Wife, Seldom, Mistress. Seld. Subtle: how now?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Look, look, the Parson joins the Doctors hand
and hers; now the Doctor kisses her by this light.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Now goes his gown off, hoy-day, he has
read breeches on: Zounds, the Physician is got
on the top of her, belike it is the mother she has,
hark the bed creaks.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: S'hart, the doors fast, break them open, we are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p:
No breaking open doors, he that stirs first
I will pop a leaden pill into his guts.
Shall purge him quite away, no haste good friends,
When they have done (what is fit) you shall not need
To break the door, they will open it themselves.

div2.stage: A curtaine drawne, a bed discouer'd, Ingen with his sword in his hand, and a Pistoll, the Ladre in a peticoate, the Parson.
the Bro. set back to back

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Thy blood base villain shall answer this
I will dye thy nuptial bed in thy hearts gore.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Come, come, my Lord, it is not so easily done,
You know it is not. For this my attempt
Upon your sister, before God and man
She was my wife, and never a bed-rid gout
Shall have my wench, to get diseases on.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Well mayst thou term her so that has consented,
Even with her will to be dishonoured.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: Not so, yet have I lain with her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: But first (witness this Priest) we both were married,

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
True it isDomine.
Their contract is run into a marriage,
And that my Lord into a carriage.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: I will undo thee Priest.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p:
It is too late,
I am undone already, wine and Tobacco, I defy thee
Thou temporal Lord, perdy thou never shalt
Keep me in jail, and hence springs my reason,
My act is neither Felony nor Treason.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Aye sir, but you do not know, what kindred she may have.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Come, come, there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
And weigh it right in my opinion my honoured Lord,
And every bodies else, this is a match,
Fitter ten thousand times, than your intent.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Most certain it is.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Besides, this Gentleman your brother-in-law well
parted, and fair meaned, and all this come about (you must
conceive) by your own sisters wit as well as his.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p:
Come, come, it is but getting of me knighted my
Lord, and I shall become your Brother well enough.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Brother your hand, Lords may have projects still,
But there is a greater Lord, will have his will.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p:
This is dispatched. Now Madam is the time,
For I long to be at it, your hand sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Now, boys.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
My Lord, and Gentlemen, I crave your witness
To what I now shall utter. Betwixt this Gentleman
There has been some love passages and myself,
Which here I free him, and take this Lady.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Law ye, and take this Lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Which with a mothers love, I give to him,
And wish all joy may crown their marriage.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Nay Madam, yet she is not satisfied.

div2.stage: Bould giues her a ring, and she puts it on her thumb.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Further, before ye all I take this ring
As an assumpsit, by the virtue of which
I bind myself in all my lands and goods,
That in his choice, I will be no hindrance:
Or by forbidding banes, or claiming him
Myself for mine, but let the match go on
Without my check, which he intendeth now.
And once again I say, I bind myself.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p:
Then once again, I say, widow thou art mine:
Priest marry us, this match I did intend,
Ye are all witnesses, if thou hinder it,
Widow your lands and goods are forfeit mine.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Ha, nay take me too, since there is no remedy,
Your Widow (without goods) sells scurvily.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Whoop, God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
S'light, I am cozened of all sides, I had good hope
of the Widow myself, but now I see everybody leaves
me saving vm, vm, vm.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: 'Troth my Lord, and that will stick by you I warrant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But how Sir, shall we salve this Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Hang her whore.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Fie, you are too uncivil.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Whore in thy face, I do defy thy taunts.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p:
Nay hold fair Lady, now I think upon it.
The old Count has no wife, let us make a match.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: If he be so contented.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Then kiss your Spouse.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: S'foot she has a beard: how now, my son?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: It is the Lord Fee-simple.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Father, lend me your sword, you and I are made a
couple of fine fools, are we not? If I were not valiant now,
and meant to beat them all, here would lie a simple disgrace
upon us, a Fee-simple one indeed, mark now what I will
say to them, do ye, hear my Masters, Dam-me, ye are all the
son of a whore, and ye lie, and I will make it good with
my sword, this is called Roaring Father.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: I will not meddle with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: You are my blood.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: And I fleshed you, you know.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: And I have a charge coming, I must not fight now.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Has either of you anything to say to me?

sp.speaker: Hush.
sp.p: Not we Sir.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Then have I something to say to you. Have you
anything to say to me?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.p: Yes marry have I Sir.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Then I have nothing to say to you, for that is the
fashion, Father if you will come away with your cough, do?
Let me see how many challenges must I get writ: You shall
here on me believe it.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p:
Nay, we will not now part angry, stay the Feasts
That must attend the weddings, you shall stay.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Why, then all friends, I thought you would not
have had the manners to bid us stay dinner neither.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p:
Then all are friends, and Lady, wife, I crown
Thy virtues with this wreath, that it may be said,
There is a good wife.

div2.stage: Thei set Girlonds on their heads.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: A Widow.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: And a Maid.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Yet mine is now approved the happiest life,
Since each of you hath changed to be a wife.
